citations.narrative:
There is a new 8ft perimeter fence on the east side of the facility, approximately 120ft long that has been placed, however
the bottom of the fence is not secured at ground level in a way to prevent animals from gaining entry into the facility or
prevent animals that escape their primary enclosures from leaving the facility under the fence line. There are multiple
holes in the soil under the fencline (approx 8 in-10 in deep) that can be used as entry/exit
points into the facility by any animal. The fence has not been finished at the bottom and requires additional maintenance
to close up the holes and gaps between the fence and the ground in order to prevent entry and exit into the facility from
under the fence.
A complete perimeter fence is required in order to protect the regulated animals from outside animals or people making
contact with their primary enclosures, and to prevent any regulated animals that escape their primary enclosure a
secondary containment area.
On or after May 17, 2000, all outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter
fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially
dangerous animals, such as, but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves,
rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The
fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons
from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the
primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the
perimeter fence.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by May 26, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is a new 8ft perimeter fence on the east side of the facility, approximately 120ft long that has been placed, however 
the bottom of the fence is not secured at ground level in a way to prevent animals from gaining entry into the facility or 
prevent animals that escape their primary enclosures from leaving the facility under the fence line. There are multiple 
holes in the soil under the fencline (approx 8 in-10 in deep) that can be used as entry/exit  
points into the facility by any animal. The fence has not been finished at the bottom and requires additional maintenance 
to close up the holes and gaps between the fence and the ground in order to prevent entry and exit into the facility from 
under the fence. 
 
A complete perimeter fence is required in order to protect the regulated animals from outside animals or people making 
contact with their primary enclosures, and to prevent any regulated animals that escape their primary enclosure a 
secondary containment area. 
 
On or after May 17, 2000, all outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter 
fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 8 feet high for potentially 
dangerous animals, such as, but not limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), bears, wolves, 
rhinoceros, and elephants, or less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The 
fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons 
from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a 
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the 
primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the 
perimeter fence. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by May 26, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.

Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
